bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Laura Reed Blincoe, April 2, 1883

div1.p: Reed teases Blincoe and her husband. He gives news of his wife and son and their life on the post, and he relates the progress of his Florida orange grove.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Laura Reed Blincoe, April 2, 1883
div1.p:
Your very
kind letters must not be
permitted to remain un=
answered any longer, if I
am one of the poorest cor=
respondents in the world. It
was real kind in you to
grasp the goose-quill and
indite a second letter to your
negligent brother. It only
goes to show what a real,
live woman, & the Mother of
some eight, ten or twelve
children (I forget the exact
figures,) can do when she
once gets up the proper
momentum! Bless you, my
Sister! that even, in your
old age, you have lost
nothing of the elasticity of your
pen or the vigor of your
mind! of course, the words
“old age” were meant only
for as “a figure of speech”, as
“Father Tom” would say. I
wonder if your fleshy hus=
band recalls the morning when
at Blacks & Blues (I mean
whites,) he read “Father Tom
& the Pope” & shook with
much glee his rotund ab=
domen! This is not “a figure
of speech”! “Indade” it's down-
right poetry (“I should say truth”)
Bedad! I don't know what's
got into this crotchety old
pen that it should write
one thing when I mean an=
other! “Howsomediver”, every-
thing is either one thing or another
thing; you won't be “after” try-
ing to contravene that prop=
osition, will you? Well, as I
was just going to say, if any=
thing be one thing, it's well
& good, & no harm's done;
but, if it be another thing,
then its plain it isn't both
things, & so can't be two things,
now what can't be two things
must be one thing, & therefore
whether its one thing or another
its all the same, & hence, as
I was about to remark
when I wandered off into
this little labyrynth, I don't
know but what the pen is
right after all! & if it is why
then all poetry is truth, &
“vice versa” (which is the clas=
sical for “shoe on the other
genieu's foot”) all truth is
poetry! which to say the least
is a “poser”! how; if your
oldest daughter or son, (for bedad, its all one to me,) wants
to try his hand at parsing,
just for edification's sake, let
him trying tackle, as we say west,
the foregoing elongated sen-
tence & then see if his or her hair
don't stand on his or her
head perpendicularly to the
surface thereof, & if it don't,
why then my powers of
prognostication are no better
than old Wiggins! I have spoken!
“whoop la”! Do you follow
me? This is only a sample;
my dear sister! Do you
like it? If so, here goes!
I may as well mention that
it is known as the “style
Enigmatical”, which is latin
for “non come atibus in
swampo up stumpo”! Aha!
if its for a “taste of the clas=
sical”, why I am right
with you! For instance, “om-
nia gallia in tres partes divisa
Est”! oh! yes it is! I know
that some people, of more im=
agination than sound learning,
say that its divided into four
parts, but believe me, I've
been there & I ought to know!
call up your oldest boy,
called sirnamed Lemuel, & if he doesn't
sustain my statement, why
I'll “skip the ditch”! However,
I remember that the S.E, or
style Enigmat, is more suited
for diplomats than for friendly
correspondents, & hence I'll drop
it like a cold potatoe! Now
lest you may infer, my dear
Sister, that your little brother
is clean daft, I will only
say that this little frolic=
someness of feelings & exu=
berance of animal spirits are
due to the fact that the sun,
which has for two weeks
hidden his face & warmth,
has just a moment ago
burst upon Fort Omaha
in all his meridian splen=
dor & has warmed the very
cockles of my heart to such
an extent that I couldn't
help it, if I had wanted to.
It was merely the gyrations
of the uncaged steed, as it were.
Well, certainly, you want to
know how I & the family are,
how we are settled, how
we like it, &c,- (I would put
several of these &c, thusly, &c, &c,
&c, &c, but I saw only the other
day that one of the &c meant
just as much as forty of the &c,
& if that is really the case, why
its really a saving of both
time & ink by making only one
&c, & that's the reason I didn't
make quite a number of them.)
Well, as I was just about to
say, before I relieved myself
of that last “chunk of learning”,
we are all well, at present,
& if our appetites are any in=
dication, I might say, “hearty”-
“Emerline”, the lady who presides
over the teapot with additional
grace, each day, has not been
so “well”, all the time, “forby” a
fall which she had last summer,
but thank heaven she has stuck
to the “hearty” right straight through
&she shows no indication of
letting go her grip, whether
any body “dark the hole” or not!
Lawrence, the hope of the “casa” (span-
ish, my dear - call up Lemuel again)
& who is said to resemble his father
in playfulness, if naught else,
grows daily more interesting.
I will say, if I am his father,
that he is as fine a sample
of a five year old kid, as
I ever saw! & you don't for=
get that I f have seen your
boys! Ho! Ho! you tickle me,
& I'll return the complement!
He has a good solid brain
& is vivacious withal. I must
narrate a remarks he made,
yesterday morning, at the break=
fast table. His mother, some
time ago, bought a small jug,
of a fancy pattern, which not=
withstanding the fact that it is
used for milk, is none the less
a jug. So yesterday morning,
when he desired a draft of
milk, he called out to the “wild
Susan”, “I say, waiter, pass
the jug”! which I really thought
was not bad, at all- The com=
bination of “waiter” & “jug”, for
a five year old, I considered
very good. The state of my
own solubility, I may say, is
good, as you may infer- Con=
cerning our household comforts
I may add that they are to
our liking & satisfaction & that
we are quite satisfied with
our station & the people are
very pleasant- We are only
4 miles from the city of Omaha,
& are not in an uncivilized
country, & surrounded by Indians,
as when in Arizona. We have
been through the coldest winter
I have ever experienced, but
we have, nevertheless, kept
quite comfortable. Our
most valued blessing is
in the shape of our good
cook which we had in
Washington- She will re=
main the rest of this year
at least, & I hope longer,
as she takes all care from
Emily on the score of provid=
ing the delicacies of the season,
so to speak. We have at our
Post nearly 400 men & 24 off=
icers, nearly as many ladies,
a good band of music &
any quantity of children!
I occasionally hear from Tom
& Kit- Hope to visit them
sometime during the year.
Annie writes me that Pa
has quite recovered & is at
his work again. Of course,
he told you about his Florida
trip. I had a letter from
my partner, to-day, stating
that he had completed plan=
ting our grove. Had put out
seven hundred & sixty five
fine trees & had excellent wea=
ther for planting- The grove is
now in good condition & as the
trees are large ones, they will
be bearing nicely in five years.
My expense so far has been
about $1000- will cost me $10 per
month for care of grove, & that
is about the only expense to
be borne. But I must close.
Emily & boy join me in best love
& kisses for your whole family,-
And, now, my dear sister,
trusting that you will not
“hide your light under a
bushel” I commend you &
yours, lovingly to the keeping
of a kind Providence.
div1.closer:
Affectionately, your brother, Walter Reed.
P.S. “If you
get there
before I do,
tell 'Em I
am coming
too”.
W.R.
